b"@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 Relay does this by merging GraphQL fragments of multiple components and doesn't issue 1 request per component"
b'@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 React does this by minimizing DOM updates'
b'@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 if you have 2 times the *2 operation in a row, you can replace it with a single *4'
b"@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 building your AST is nice because it's high level (can go a lot higher than list.map) and you can optimize"
b"@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 this example is dumb as it's pretty useless, but you get the idea"
b'@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 list.map(x => x*2) would look like that in imperative programming: https://t.co/InFg8xgb66'
b'@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 it is exactly that for the browser developers. But will you build your own AST on top of this AST?'
b'@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 you can also mix imperative/declarative. Redux-saga put functions into the json AST @YassineElouafi2'
b'@iammerrick @tylermcginnis33 not sure to understand what you mean by "serialize"'
b"@tylermcginnis33 @iammerrick to go further I'd recommend this article: https://t.co/aGFQVGG51Z"
b'@tylermcginnis33 @iammerrick ReactElement, GraphQL/Relay and Redux-saga effects all go through a json representation before being run'
b"@tylermcginnis33 @iammerrick ie if your operation is not encoded in json before being run, it's imperative"
b'@tylermcginnis33 @iammerrick declarative means you build your own AST and run it against an interpreter'
b"@tylermcginnis33 @iammerrick it's not subjective. list.map(x => x * 2) is not declarative: it just raises the abstraction level"
b'@tylermcginnis33 @iammerrick your article is nice, but unfortunatly there is a strict line between imperative and declarative code'
